prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information in Historical Context

para.paratext: Property law concepts were created during medieval times when land was the central source of wealth. During the Dark Ages, land was the central source of subsistence. The Feudal Age was a reaction to the Dark Ages, and a complex system of rights and obligations was developed to satisfy the need for order and security. In the Feudal Age, land was used as a means of survival, and was also expanded to create a system of wealth and a complex system of organized agricultural production and physical protection for both master and serf.
The feudal system was a system where status, not private agreements, determined the activities of the members of that society.[1] One writer has put it this way:

One man, the vassal, commends to another man,whom he chooses as his master … the vassal owes his master fealty, counsel, military and material assistance. The master—the lord—owes his vassal fealty, protection and the means of subsistence. This last can be provided in various ways, usually by conceding to the vassal a piece of land known as a “benefice” or “fief”. Thus the hierarchy among individuals was very soon accompanied by a hierarchy of rights over land, due to an “extreme parcelling out of property rights”.[2]

It was also at this time that the concept of trade secrets arose to keep the secrets of one guild from members of other guilds. However, there were few problems with copying because reproduction of textual or visual images was done by hand, rendering it difficult to copy the work of another. Writings were generally the works of religious scholars, and it was believed that if more copies were made, this would better advance the cause of religion.

G. Klueck, “The Coming Jurisprudence of the Information Age: Examinations of the Three Past Socio-Economic Ages Suggest the Future” (1984), 21 San Diego L. Rev. 1077, 1082. See also Statute of Labourers, 1349 (U.K.), 23 Edw. 3. This statute provided that able-bodied persons were to work at reasonable rates and were not to refuse to work for anyone.
G. Fourquin, Lordship and Feudalism in the Middle Ages, I. and A.L. Lytton Sells, trans. (London: Allen & Unwin, 1976), p. 11.
